PS> 一般来说提交pull request可以这么做：新建一个branch，从上游库git rebase（不用git merge，因为这会增加一个额外的commit），然后做相应的修改，最后从这个branch来提交pull request。pull request被merge或者关闭之后，这个branch可以直接删除。
如果直接从head branch的master提交pull request，而master又有base branch的历史中不包含的commits时，pull request就会自动把这些commits全部包括进来（像你上面这样）。

html = get_html("http://music.baidu.com/song/%s" % sid)
url = r1(r'download_url="([^"]+)"', html)
title = r1(r'sname="([^"]+)"', html)

. Good job anyway, the commit is kind of a mess...
1. Please don't keep irrelevant files in commits; instead, reset them and force push back again.
2. In the code, (videobam.py)
old_fake_headers = fake_headers
fake_hreaders = old_fake_headers
What are...those?
3. You don't change the version number. If every pull request comes with its own arbitrary version number, then no one can keep track of them. A pull request is a bunch of commits that fix something, nothing more. Some PRs came earlier but some others might be merged sooner, we don't know that. So don't mess with the version number anyway.
4. The file permission is 644, please don't change this (is it your Intellij IDE changed it for you?)
Most of our contributors write code in emacs or vim, so we haven't ignored .* in .gitignore (better if we do). When working in an IDE, you just need to be careful about those project files generated by IDE.
Basically I don't care about code quality too much (as long as it implements something it's always welcome), we can improve it later. But I'd like to see commits that are simple and clean (no unnecessary change).
In this case, just having one commit that adds necessary code to common.py and extractors/ would be perfect.
. Nevermind.
It seems you used songtaste.py as a template. I don't even remember why these code are there, but they should be removed (both in songtaste.py and your videobam.py).
You don't have to withdraw a pull request - you can just reset everything and git push --force to the same branch, and old commits shall be gone. Anyway, it does no harm to start a new one.
. Perfect. Thank you!
. Version numbers like N-64706-g2f71aeb and n2.3-8-g2f71aeb are composed of: revision number/release branch + git hash. Some stable branches (like n1.0.10) are even older than 1.1; we might need to consider 1.0 as a fallback.
. There is even a 0.5 branch, which they are still maintaining:
https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/releases/tag/n0.5.14
Old stable branches like these don't have a concat demuxer - I guess a better solution is to handle everything in exceptions, so we don't need to know the version number at all. For now, choosing 1.0 will make sure everything works (even for branches like 0.5 and 1.0)

According to the document:

Changed in version 3.3: ASCII-only Unicode strings are now accepted by the decoding functions of the modern interface.

. It's very reasonable to keep our code compatible with Python 3.1 & 3.2. (although it already works well on 3.3 & 3.4)
I'm changing it to:
py
base64.b64decode(bytes(ep, 'ascii'))
No more extra check to see if ep needs to be converted to a bytes type, we can always use it as bytes, since this will work on any version of python 3.x. Just to get rid of these unthoughtful changes in Python.

. @Snise 和你的操作无关。@0x00-pl 用他的 develop branch 开了这个 pull request，在我处理这两个 PR 之前，他把 #448 的内容 merge 到了他的 develop branch 里，然后就会出现在这个 PR 里。
你用哪个 branch 来提交 pull request，之后这个 branch 里所有新的修改都会自动变成这个 PR 的一部分。所以提交 PR 的时候最好是新开一个 branch，不要用自己的主线分支。
@Snise 你的 #448 是在网页上直接操作的，GitHub 自动新建了一个 patch-1 分支，所以不存在这个问题。

. any_download is used internally - Generally it's not a good idea to use it as a stable API, since I'm planning to refactor all the legacy code.
The trick is that we convert all URLs to http form (and handle redirects when possible) before passing them to any_download, therefore it's not needed to take https patterns into consideration inside extractors (personally I see no necessity to download videos via HTTPS, though I know it's arguable).
Please feel free to do so as long as it meets your needs (just be aware that your regexp failed the test because it doesn't match http://.)

. The plan is to support the old plaintext cookies.txt, Mozilla cookies.splite and Chrome Default/Cookies. I'm not merging this til we're fully done.
. Implementing Chromium cookies is non-trivial job - the encrypted_value stored in SQLite was encrypted using AES (therefore we need a 3rd party crypto library like pycrypto to handle the algorithmic thing).
Even more sophisticated, based on this article http://n8henrie.com/2013/11/use-chromes-cookies-for-easier-downloading-with-python-requests/, the encryption methods differ on Linux and OS X (didn't mention Windows).
Forget about Chrome, fair enough to support moz_cookies and cookies.txt only.
(To my knowledge, not only Firefox, but also some WebKit based browsers such as GNOME Web, makes use of moz_cookies too)
. :ok_hand: 
. As I started to rethink, #377 is not really a good idea. For many videos on Bilibili, partitions are not necessarily bound together (might be different episodes, like this one) it's problematic to merge all these partitions.
you-get should download the exact partition which user requires. For all other partitions, use the -l option to download the whole playlist (and no merging will be carried out).
. Due to the big size of high-resolution DASH videos, and the audio/video track merging process which relies on FFmpeg, we are not going to make the best quality DASH video as a default for downloading. Instead, users should select whatever they want via the given --itag option.
Here's a 1080p example (of relatively small size) to test with:
$ you-get --itag=137 youtu.be/C7xSFmsvflk
And here's a very big one, which has a 4K resolution (3840 x 2160): (it played quite choppy in VLC on my laptop, but whatever...)
$ you-get -i https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k4MWgNsxd_c
. It takes 2 times user time to finish extracting video info (for deciphering every signature it counters, but not really necessary). This needs to be improved.

Instead of "Merge pull request #1 from soimort/develop", remember to do a rebase against soimort/develop next time.
. Note that universal.py already parses the page (it comes with some noises, so it's still good to have a domain-specific veoh.py). Instead of adding more and more extractors, you-get should be focusing more on a general solution in the future.
. By "general solution", I mean simply extracting direct links (like exactly what you did in this PR) and (possibly) apply statistical methods to pick up whatever users might want (That's how I imagine the roadmap of you-get 0.4, 0.5, 0.6... goes)
For now I don't have plans for supporting more and more mid-sized websites, mainly for two reasons: 1. I don't even visit them and I don't have to download videos from them; 2. Due to the growing size of extractors, I'm not sure if I can maintain such a large repository. So these will eventually be crowdsourced to people, like brew taps & formulas. Feel free to add more extractors to you-get, but be prepared to put them into your repositories someday. That'll be the next big release of you-get (1.0).
I'm not talking about fullstack DOM simulation right now, but I'm looking into the possibility of using WebEngine / Chromium to scrape web pages, with a PhantomJS like interface together with Pepper API support. It's kind out of scope for you-get (which is just a loose collection of juicy Python scripts), and it requires hardcore programming in C++ and Node. And this will not happen before 2016.

42 was chosen because it's the answer given by the following calculation:
console
100.0% (999.9/999.9MB) ├████████████████████████████████████████┤[99/99] 1000 MB/s
|0                   24|                                        |0             18|
24 + 18 = 42.
Of course it won't fit videos larger than 1GB or that consist of more than 99 pieces, or even net speed faster than 9999MBps. But in practice, 42 is the best number we'd have. :satisfied:

The current structure of codebase is a mess: mixture of OOP and non-OOP (legacy) code, inconsistent coding style, quick hacks and patches merged without much thought.

. Firstly, thanks for the pull request.
A rough review:
Your implementation of huaban_download_board() perfectly ignored the current structure of you-get - it has its own version of progress bar, own file handling, own stdout printing/logging, and even own KeyboardInterrupt exception catching (why?).
The code is not wrong - but as it differs quite a lot from you-get's coding style, it will make itself extremely hard to maintain. If we improve any high-level routine in common,py, the code here will not benefit from our changes much, or even risk to break (e.g. it relies on some low-level API like url_save, which is not supposed to be used by extractors directly).
Especially, if you want to propose an enhancement to the current progress bar, or anything else that could be shared among all extractors, please consider doing a patch on common.py, instead of putting them all together specific to one site, isolated.
. > For the progress bar, I wish its animation is based on the count of pieces of files rather than the size, 

because it isn't worth to make hundreds of connections to check the images' size of a "board".

That is a very good point, and that's why I prefer you to make those changes in common.py, rather than do it in your own huaban.py.
download_urls does support only one extension, and you're also right, that the default naming scheme is based on the number of pieces (starting from 0). I haven't tested your PR on a real machine yet, but I guess you could just call download_urls as many times as want; doing that won't look very nice, though.
Or, if you can abstract some of these functionalities as common routines, put them into a common place (common.py) so later implemented extractors can benefit from them.

Lastly, it seems I misunderstood the exception handling strategy in youku.py

Oh, forgot to say, but the KeyboardInterrupt in youku.py is used to skip a certain video when downloading a playlist (so if you have a video you don't like, Ctrl-C will let you skip it, instead of terminating the whole downloading process)
. Actually I prefer the progress bar (probably other things also) to be fixed in common.py. For now, removing EnhancedPiecesProgressBarand simply making use of download_urls() will do the job.
I don't have time to refactor this part of common.py, so let's keep things simple that if I want to rewrite the whole codebase someway, simpler extractors would be easier to improve, i.e., the shorter, the better.
(Tip: it's completely up to you whether you would intend to change that, since you can always keep it as your own fork of you-get.)
Making hundreds of HEAD requests to check for all pieces' sizes, as you said, is inefficient for image downloading. The cause is, you-get was designed to be a video downloader (normally there won't be too many pieces for a video), so handling images wasn't my concern at the very beginning. Certainly, we have extended its scope to image downloading now.

. Too many test cases will slow down our code integration with Travis and increase the probability of temporary failure (due to inaccessible servers or network status), that's why I haven't added more tests throughout years, in spite of our growing number of extractors.
Also, from my experience, extractors break down from time to time. If we can't fix any broken extractor immediately, then the whole status will be shown as "Failed", which would render our Travis tests for PR/commits useless, until we fix that specific site. Since Travis CI is mainly used for guaranteeing the PRs actually run (across various Python 3.x versions), it's actually wiser not to do intensive tests on extractors. A small number for commonly-used sites (e.g. YouTube) would suffice.

. The code itself is ok, but I'm skeptical about the reliability of using 3rd party services (especially, when they are random selected).
What if the auto-selected proxy is malicious, or just behaves strangely without forwarding data correctly? We have no guarantee about this, and  I don't want to mislead users to think that this is a you-get issue.
. Sorry for the late response.

In the current implementation, the proxy isn't working for around 30% of the time. This is still much better than picking proxies on my own

True. I don't know anything about ProxyNova, how it operates and provides these free proxy services, but I can imagine that they are not as reliable as you may think. It claims to enable anonymity, but you could achieve the same thing via Tor as well. Instead of that we pick an arbitrary proxy for users, they must be aware of the transparency and the risk (there's very little risk if you're only going to download videos though) of using it -- and if they really do, they would just pick their own. Thus I'm reluctant to let you-get do this for users.
As for now, "picking a freely available proxy" was never my intent; I want to use just my own proxy, so it's not really a priority for me.

...and stop using it if the result doesn't look reasonable. We may try a couple of proxies in parallel first, and then pick a random one only from the ones that are known to work

How? IMHO we should not handle that level of complexity, for this simple command-line tool that uses regexp to scrape the web. We are not going to make it a fault-tolerant, server middleware anyway.
As a follow-up on the technical side: BeautifulSoup is cool, but we are not going to introduce any external dependency to this simple tool at this stage.

. Thanks for your contribution, but I wonder why it is worth spending so much effort on coloring output; that's not even the focus of this project. More importantly: too many rich colors will sometimes make the text hard to read, since different users may have quite different terminal backgrounds. A set of colors that looks good on dark background may look unreadable on light background, et vice versa.  That's why I'm conservative on this.
Also, please: No Chinese in the source code. All comments should be written in simple, easy-to-read English. (unless it's a proper noun refers to non-English name, e.g. 优酷)
Furthermore, if you have doubts about some pieces of code, or if you think something in the existing code might have a mistake, such like:
diff
+#恕我愚昧，看不懂上面的语句，极度怀疑是：
+sys.path.insert(1, _filepath)
+sys.path.insert(1, _srcdir)
Please always open an issue to ask us first (for example #1135) or a separate PR to explain why this should be changed, instead of inserting these questioning words in the source code and sending them as a pull request. We can't merge these things.
. (TL;DR just read the last two paragraphs.)

First, plain text are ugly especially in cmd of my windows

Fair enough, and I know it looks ugly on Windows' cmd, because I had to package this software and test it on a Windows box from time to time. But essentially, everything looks ugly on cmd.

We can pre-establish all kind of Theme,such as all-blank-theame to solve it.

Theming is beyond the current scope of this project. Personally I like your idea of implementing themes (I have other open-source project that involves some form of theming, e.g. translate-shell), but I would rather not to do it in you-get prematurely.

But I understand that you get bored with too much code,even there is only 4 api

More code means we are obliged to maintain them. So it's not just about the API.
Making a one-time, big patch is easy for any trained programmer to do, but no one can guarantee they are perfect in the first place, and chasing bugs caused by someone else's code is not really a nice experience. You'll understand it someday: Simplicity of maintenance is much, much more important than just adding fancy, unnecessary stuff infinitely.

actually, "but I wonder why it is worth spending so much effort on coloring output; that's not even the focus of this project." irritate me.

I'm sorry if it irritated you, but let me stress this advice again: (also to future contributors) If you wish to make a significant change to the project (perhaps to any well-known open-source project), always ask the maintainers and discuss about it first. If you know what kind of changes should be allowed, you won't feel bad after spending a lot of time, only working on something the project owner doesn't want.

I don't know what is the project focus on

This project mainly focuses on pulling videos (sometimes other interesting stuff) from the web, I assume you already knew that. If you can pick one of existing issues and fix that, you're more than welcome! (we have a hell lot of extractors broken at this moment)
Actually I would suggest you to publish your code here on PyPI as an individual library, so anyone who wants to use these coloring functions in their project can add your library as a dependency. That could benefit the whole Python community, and we are free of the overhead to maintain them in you-get. What do you think?

Anyway ,It's Your Code, you can do anything.But Do NOT behave as there is a team to Supply Support ,Please.

Yes, it is our code (all 70 contributors'), although I wrote the most part and have the final say (simply because I own this repository). And you're also right, there is no team to supply support, because nobody is getting paid to do that. Everyone (even myself) is volunteering their free time to contribute to this project.

Only you have ssh-key didnt you?

Then I'm not sure what that means. Technically everyone has "an SSH-key" on GitHub.
If you mean "write access", then Top 3 contributors on the list are all project collaborators who can push to this repository. They helped me a lot on explaining things, fixing issues I'm not able (or don't care) to fix, reviewing other peoples' Pull Requests and merging commits by their own judgment. Please, DO NOT ignore them.

I understand that it is bitter to get your first Pull Request rejected, but this is just how things work (in open source). I have code that I've written then thrown away myself (because they're too complicated, unnecessary, I have no intent to maintain...), so it's not really a big deal, and there's no point to overreact on the denial of a pull request at all.
Again, thank you for taking your time. You're very welcome if you want to start by contributing something small (which doesn't take you too much time, but still helpful to everyone). And I hope our words didn't hurt your feelings anyway. We are harsh sometimes, that's because we want to keep the right things on track.
Cheers!

master  # 用于保存自己的一些features
 sync    # 用于与上游仓库同步
目前 sync 比 upstream/master 少一次提交，尝试：
git fetch upstream
git checkout sync
git rebase upstream/master
之后，产生了大量冲突，而且变成了 detached HEAD。
. 查看了一下 sync 和 upstream/master 的提交记录，最近3次sha1都不一样。
解决冲突，接着git rebase --continue，然后git rebase --skip，如此重复几次之后，终于正常了。

    # baidu pan link
    sourceLink = r1(r'"link-src-info"><a href="([^"]+)"', html)

        sourceLink = sourceLink.replace('&', '&')
    sourceHtml = get_html(sourceLink) if sourceLink != None else None

    songLink =  r1(r'\\"dlink\\":\\"([^"]*)\\"', sourceHtml).replace('\\\\/', '/') if sourceLink != None else r1(r'download_url="([^"]+)"', html)
    songName = parse.unquote(r1(r'songname=([^&]+)&', html))

    albumName = parse.unquote(r1(r'songartistname=([^&]+)&', html))
    lrcLink = r1(r'data-lyricdata=\'{ "href":"([^"]+)"', html)

                                  'songName'   : songName,

m13253:
I would like to mention that, the quickest way to remove non-ASCII chars is to:
some_string.encode('ascii', 'ignore').decode('ascii')
Or if you want to replace undecodable chars with a placeholder:
some_string.encode('ascii', 'replace').decode('ascii').replace('?', '_')
It is stupid to scan over the string with a for-loop.

```
!/usr/bin/env python
all = ['douyutv_download']
from ..common import *
import json
import hashlib
import time
import random
import string
import urllib.parse, urllib.request
def douyutv_download(url, output_dir = '.', merge = True, info_only = False, **kwargs):
    room_id = url[url.rfind('/')+1:]
json_request_url = "http://m.douyu.com/html5/live?roomId=%s" % room_id
content = get_content(json_request_url)
data = json.loads(content)['data']
server_status = data.get('error',0)
if server_status is not 0:
    raise ValueError("Server returned error:%s" % server_status)

title = data.get('room_name')
show_status = data.get('show_status')
if show_status is not "1":
    raise ValueError("The live stream is not online! (Errno:%s)" % server_status)

tt = int(time.time() / 60)
did = ''.join([random.choice(string.ascii_uppercase + string.digits) for n in range(32)])
sign_content = '{room_id}{did}A12Svb&%1UUmf@hC{tt}'.format(room_id = room_id, did = did, tt = tt)

sign = hashlib.md5(sign_content.encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()

json_request_url = "http://www.douyu.com/lapi/live/getPlay/%s" % room_id

payload = {'cdn': 'ws', 'rate': '0', 'tt': tt, 'did': did, 'sign': sign}

json_data = json.dumps(payload).encode('utf8')

postdata = urllib.parse.urlencode(payload)

req = urllib.request.Request(json_request_url, postdata.encode('utf-8'))

with urllib.request.urlopen(req) as response:
    the_page = response.read()

content = json.loads(the_page.decode('utf-8'))
data = content['data']

server_status = data.get('error',0)
if server_status is not 0:
    raise ValueError("Server returned error:%s" % server_status)

real_url = data.get('rtmp_url')+'/'+data.get('rtmp_live')

print_info(site_info, title, 'flv', float('inf'))
if not info_only:
    print(real_url)
    download_url_ffmpeg(real_url, title, 'flv', None, output_dir, merge = merge)

site_info = "douyu.com"
download = douyutv_download
download_playlist = playlist_not_supported('douyu')
```

~~There are't HTTP Error 403 in my tests yet.  ~~
~~What's the url you are testing?~~
The HTTP Error 403 comes out when requesting k.youku.com.
. You can open the k.youku.com url in browser.
There are two ways to fix it.Depends on the yxon=1 parameter in the end of k.youku.com url.
1.Now the k.youku.com url doesn't have yxon=1 parameter,We can add http headers or cookies for downloading.But the -p argument in you-get may be corrupted.
2.if we add yxon=1 to the k.youku.com.The url will be k.youku.com/......&yxon=1.And it will give back a string which contain a url of video.You can test it in browser.And that url doesn't  need special  http headers or cookies. 
3.Of course,you also can obtain the final video address from the answer headers of HEAD request to k.youku.com.
. Yes,the k.youku.com also requires cookies.Use browser's incognito mode,it indeed give back 403 Error to me.
. I think this is not a mature method.This will confuse some users when the request can't return cookies and throw out HTTP 403 forbidden error.And a cookie manager would be better.The feature of cookie manager would be:
- save the cookies for later use.
- renew the cookies when cookies expire.
We can reproduce  this error from this command.
curl -i 'http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XNDQzNTIyMDQ0.html?from=y1.6-100.3.1.a7c275ecd7b411e1a19e' |less
When there are Age: 0 and X-Cache: Miss from x.v.qd in return header.The cookies will be returned.If we run this command some times.There will aren't cookies returned.Only if the age reach to max-age=900.
. Yes.This is a temporary fix.But it isn't perfect.

. about 1fc754a94fce84a2154ca03cf950c284d234063f
Single songs downloaded via you-get were named as "title - album - artist.mp3",
while songs in showcollect were named as "#.title - artist - album.mp3"
Following is my reason to unify the order of album & artist in filename:
Since the mp3 files downloaded from Xiami in this way have no id3 tags,  filename is the only way to identify them or to re-construct id3 tags. 
E.g. If someone writes a simple script using id3 to generate id3v2 tags for these mp3 files according to the filename, these different formats lead to confusion.

. @cnbeining Per #1477 , I found this annoying site has assigned different URLs to different chunks of the video (approx. 15 MB/chunk). So is there any way for you-get download module to do something like this?
. Pre-requirement: PR #1478 
Because this site requires to change URL (setting Range parameter will cause 403 Forbidden or 405 Not Allowed) when downloading different chunks of the video file 
. If everything works, this will close #1477
. > Any special reason to use url_save_chunked rather than url_save?

(The first one was intended for downloading data with chunked transfer encoding, if I recall correctly. Based on my rough observation, this is not the case for icourses.cn. It has a conventional Content-Length :)

Well, if you try to use wget curl or something to download the video, you'll notice the server hang up (kill) the connection by force when you download approx. 15MB of data. A workaround in #1478 add some special functions to url_save_chunked (reason why is thaturl_save is used by almost every other sites, so it may break everything if I modified that) to dynamically update URLs when downloaded chunk reaches 15 MB

It has a conventional Content-Length :)

Yes and no, when you change the URL to try to seek the stream, you'll notice the Content-Length no longer rational. And Range parameter will cause server to return 405 Not Allowed
. This should be a pre-requirement for #1472

Echoing back the URL is at best slightly more clear when users are downloading multiple videos, but even then due to the sequential nature of you-get, it's extremely easy to know exactly which URL the warning applies to.
Note that currently error messages don't contain original URLs either. Not following conventions makes the (frankly already quite inconsistent, due to its nature) project inconsistent.

There are two reasons make me feel hard to fit the download process of Huaban into the workflow provided by common.py.
First, there maybe multiple types of images in one "board". download_urls accepts only one extension name for a whole stream, and also print_info.
The second one is new images will be added into a "board". I want to continuously download images from a "board", but the default naming scheme is based on current number of files to be downloaded.
The reasons above explained why I have my own versions of file handling and logging.
For the progress bar, I wish its animation is based on the count of pieces of files rather than the size, because it isn't worth to make hundreds of connections to check the images' size of a "board". SimpleProgressBar's animation is based on size and PiecesProgressBar just count down the number.
Lastly, it seems I misunderstood the exception handling strategy in youku.py, it raise the KeyboardInterrupt but I bypass it. :disappointed: 
@soimort 
. > you could just call download_urls as many times as want

xuehuichao:
Thanks for your comments!
I guess we can split our discussions into two layers: (1) fundamentally, do we want this feature in you-get? (2) technically, how can we improve the current implementation, if we decide to have this feature.
- Is the proxy website reliable (e.g. will it be down, or will its format change)?
- Are the listed proxies valid (e.g. malicious, or down)?
I guess the technical issues can all be resolved, but the most fundamental question is whether you folks would want this feature included in you-get. I personally think this feature would be worthwhile, as a lot of users want to download from Chinese video websites, and it's a lot of pain finding proxies manually. With that said, I would totally understand if you think the proxy picker should be implemented in a separate tool.
Regarding the technical details:
- Proxy listing website's reliability: I think we may in the long run (1) avoid putting all eggs into the same basket by implementing proxy pickers using other proxy listing websites (2) implement some tests to check for format changes etc.
- The listed proxies may not be valid. This is a very valid concern. In the current implementation, the proxy isn't working for around 30% of the time. This is still much better than picking proxies on my own, but it definitely has made you-get look less reliable. I think one way to mitigate it is to double check the proxy's validity before we initiate the actual download. For example, we may first try using the proxy to download a cnn.com page, and stop using it if the result doesn't look reasonable. We may try a couple of proxies in parallel first, and then pick a random one only from the ones that are known to work. Does that make sense?
Please let me know what you think.
.

如果最终 real url 是 m3u8，那么比如 you-get -p mpv 这样的应用，希望得到 m3u8 地址，而不是 general_m3u8_extractor 分解后的很多行的 ts 地址，这个 ts 并不适合用来播放。

After some tests now I believe timeout param should be removed. Socket blocking for one second is quite normal in the real world. Timeout after only one second sounds somewhat insane. urlopen_with_retry can also catch socket.timeout exception so this can mess up the control flow.
In this patch it is kept with timeout set to 15 for there could be a chance someone really need it. If anyone would like to bypass IP limitations with short timeout, please change it to a rather short time period(F. I. 1 in the old commit).

测试之后我发现timeout确实应该被移除，socket timeout指的应该是socket block的时间，实际上socket block 1秒，没数据可以读写，是非常正常的事情（比如线路繁忙，比如无线网稍微波动了一下），所以1秒就超时可能有点过了。另外urlopen_with_retry也会捕获socket.timeout这个异常，所以流程控制会变得混乱。
但在这个patch里，timeout还是有的，但是默认值是15. 如果有人需要用这个超时来完成一些事情，比如觉得这个patch还不如原来的好用，把timeout的值改短就行了，例如改成原来的1。. 对于某些HTTPError 403 503的情况，如#1913 #1938 （在后半，没有开新issue）
